questions.question: A 20-year-old male who was consulting a 30-year-old male therapist said to the therapist that he cares just like his brother. Which of the following statements is true regarding this scenario?

options.B: Can interfere with the treatment of this patient
options.D: The patient is always consciously aware of such feelings

questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) Can interfere with the treatment of this patient Explanation: A patient developing feelings (like his brother) for the therapist is suggestive of Transference (not Countertransference - Option A) . Transference and countertransference: Transference Countertransference Feelings of a patient towards the therapist Feelings of a therapist towards patient Can be positive or negative (Option C) Can be both conscious and unconscious (predominantly unconscious) (Option D) Interferes with treatment of the patient (Option B) (as there could be exaggerated/diminished reactions due to this) Reference: Kaplan & Saddock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th Edition, Pages 29, 30

questions.question: All of the following are components of the topographical model of mind described by Sigmund Freud except
questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) Subconscious mind Explanation: The subconscious mind is not a component of the Topographical model described by Sigmund Freud. Topographical model of mind (Sigmund Freud): The unconscious mind can be reached by, Psychoanalysis Dream analysis Psychoanalysis Dream analysis Techniques to bring out the direct unconscious mind (crossing the repression barrier). The process involved in the conversion of a Latent dream (unconscious mind) to a Manifest dream (conscious mind) is known as Dreamwork. Psychoanalysis techniques: Hypnosis Free association (patient is allowed to talk uninterrupted) Parapraxis (slip tongue) Abreaction (recollection of repressed memories with the release of emotions by methods like the use of thiopentone - the same principle used in Narco analysis ) Dreamwork: Condensation Displacement Symbolic representation Secondary revision Reference: Kaplan & Saddock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th Edition, Pages 3320-3325

questions.question: Analyze the following statements regarding the structural model of mind and choose the correct set of true statements from these 1) Ego lies in all three- conscious, preconscious & unconscious parts of the mind 2) Instinctual drives are a part of Id. 3) The superego is mostly present in the conscious part of the mind.
questions.explanation: Correct answer: A) 1,2 Explanation: Structural model of mind (by Sigmund Freud): Id: Instinctive drives Based on the pleasure principle (immediate gratification) Operates under primary processes Lies in the unconscious mind Ego: The executive organ of the mind Maintains balance between Id and Superego Works on the reality principle Lies in all three - conscious, preconscious and unconscious parts of the mind Superego: Moral compass insisting on socially acceptable behavior Develops after 5 years (after resolution of oedipal complex) Predominantly present in the unconscious part of the mind Reference: Kaplan & Saddock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th Edition, Page 3339-3341 (PDF)

questions.question: Karthik says ‘Siddharth hates me’, but in reality Karthik hates Siddharth. What kind of defense mechanism is this?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: A) Projection Explanation: Here the person projects his own thoughts onto someone else, this type of defense mechanism is known as Projection - a part of narcissistic defenses. Narcissistic Defenses: Defense Features Example Projection (Option A) A person projects his own thoughts onto someone else. Seen in psychosis. Mr.P is having an affair but is convinced that his wife has an affair. Denial (Option B) Refuse to accept reality Usually used to avoid some painful stimuli Refusal to admit to having a serious illness Distortion (Option D) Reshaping external reality in a person’s favor to suit his/her inner needs Mr.X believed that his boss was rude to him because in fact he likes X more than anyone else Splitting Viewing people/things in the world as either good/bad without considering the whole range. Seen in Borderline personality disorder. Seeing all people without moustache as feminine. Regression (Option C): Type of immature defense. A person returns to an earlier stage of development (acts childish). Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th Edition, Page 3345,3346

questions.question: All of the following are neurotic defenses except
questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) Regression Explanation: Regression is a type of immature defense mechanism, not neurotic. Regression is the return to an earlier stage of development (act childish/ younger). Example: Husband returns after a stressful day, and converses with wife in baby talks. Neurotic defenses: Defense Features Example Inhibition Unconsciously limiting an aim and accepting partial fulfilment of desire. If a person is unable to clear the entrance exam for MBBS, he becomes a veterinary doctor. Intellectualization Excessive use of intellect to escape painful emotions. After getting diagnosed with a metastatic tumor, a person starts discussing a great deal about its technical aspects. Isolation of affect Separation of emotions related to a stressful event, but reality is accepted. A man comes home and tells his family of his lung cancer without any emotions. Displacement (Option A) Unconscious shifting of impulses from one object to another, to solve a conflict. A man gets angry with his boss and shouts at his wife, the wife shouts at her son, and the son punches his toy. Dissociation Separation of one or more mental functions from remaining functions to avoid distress. A person was kidnapped and tortured, he says it was as if he was floating on the ceiling and watching it. Undoing (Option D) An act to nullify a previous act. Performing compulsions in OCD, apologizing. Rationalisation Giving logical explanations for unacceptable behaviors. Seen in Substance use disorders. A person says he drinks alcohol because it kills all the germs in his body. Reaction formation Doing the reverse of your unacceptable emotions. Over Caring for the person you don’t like. Repression (Option C) Unconscious forgetting Such memories (stored in the preconscious mind) can be brought out by techniques like Hypnosis/free association. A child has been abused by his mother, and now has no memory of that abuse. Externalisation Perceiving one’s personality (mood/impulses/etc.) within the external world. Similar to projection. An argumentative type of person believes others are arguing while the personal self is blameless. Retroflexion Unconscious projection of another's personality to one’s hostility. Mr.X (arrogant and short-tempered in reality) hates me because I am not worth enough. Reference: Kaplan & Saddock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th Edition, Pages 3349-3351

questions.question: Leena, the sister of Garv disciplines her brother like her mother would when she isn’t home. What type of defense is being followed here?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: D) Introjection Explanation: Attributing to oneself the qualities of another is called Introjection - a type of immature defense mechanism. Immature defenses: Defense Features Example Blocking Inhibition of thinking (temporary) is associated with a component of tension (inability to remember). A student unable to recall the answer in the exam (temporary), but recalls as he comes out of the exam. Acting out Unconscious wishes are enacted in behavior to avoid being aware of them. Seen in impulse control disorders. A student is angry with his friend, Rather than telling him he throws a book at him (not intentionally). Regression Return to an earlier stage of development (act childish/ younger). Husband returns after a stressful day, and converses with wife in baby talks. Introjection (Option D) Opposite to projection. Attributing to oneself the qualities of another. Stockholm syndrome: Hostages get sympathetic towards their captors. People often treat their children the same way their parents treat them. Projective identification A person projects some aspect of himself onto someone else. Tries to coerce another person into identifying that he/she is projected. Seen in Borderline personality disorder. The wife is aggressive toward the husband, then the husband also shows his aggressiveness. Somatization Unconscious moments are converted to bodily/ physical moments. Getting a headache while taking exams. Hypo- chondriasis Unconscious transforming of unacceptable impulses to unrelated somatic complaints of pain, and illness. Exaggerating a physical symptom (e.g. headache) for the purpose of regression. Passive aggression Indirectly expressing aggression towards others. Refusing to take medications after a family quarrel. Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th Edition, Page 3346-3349

questions.question: A medical student feeling overwhelmed by academic pressure starts writing short stories in her free time. Through creative writing, she transforms her anxiety into a productive outlet. What kind of defense mechanism is this?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Sublimation Explanation: Since the subject is channelling emotional conflicts into creative or physical activities, this is an example of sublimation Mature defences: Affiliation The subject seeks help or advice not to have the problem solved by others, but to find a solution they can implement themselves, and learn from emotionally meaningful interactions. (Option A ruled out) Going to therapy/supportive group/spiritual/etc. Altruism The subject helps others with problems they cannot handle alone, finding personal meaning and gratification in helping, often tied to similar past experiences. (Option B ruled out) After the death of the husband, due to smoking, the wife starts a 'No smoking' campaign. Anticipation The subject prepares emotionally for upcoming stressful situations by thinking ahead, imagining outcomes, and planning how to cope. After failing the exam, the student plans to argue while going home. Humor The subject uses humor to diffuse tension in difficult or embarrassing situations, often making self-deprecatory or ironic remarks to lighten the mood without harm. A man comes out and laughs after getting scolded by the boss. Self-assertion The subject confidently expresses thoughts, wishes, or feelings, deals with their own needs directly, and stands up for themselves in emotionally difficult situations. (Option C ruled out) The wife tells her alcoholic husband to choose between her (or) alcohol and leaves the house. Sublimation The subject channels emotional conflicts into socially valued ones creative or physical activities, finding satisfaction or mastery in the process. (Option D) A child gets angry at being scolded at home and scores 100 runs in a school cricket match. Suppression The subject consciously sets aside desires or emotions that may lead to bad consequences, postponing emotional responses to handle immediate, urgent tasks effectively. A student decides to forget about the upcoming exam and take a day's break. Reference: The Hierarchy of Defense Mechanisms: Assessing Defensive Functioning With the Defense Mechanisms Rating Scales Q-Sort

questions.question: Given are various stages of psychosexual development. Which stage of development is a 4-year-old in?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Stage III Explanation: 3-5-year-old child is in stage III-phallic stage of psychosexual development Freud’s 5 stages of psychosexual maturation: Stage Age Range Erogenous Zone (Center of pleasure) Explanation Stage I: Oral 0-1 .5 year (Option A ruled out) Mouth Example- feeding (gratification for baby’s oral needs) Fixation: Schizophrenia, substance dependence Stage II: Anal 1-3 years (Option B ruled out) Bowel Toilet training is central Control over sphincters especially anal sphincter Fixation: OCD, OCPD Stage III: Phallic 3- 5 years (Option C) Genitalia Development of the Oedipus (or) Electra complex occurs. Stage IV: Latency 5- 6 to 11-13 years (Option D ruled out) Dormant (no specific zone) Focus on school, sports, and social relationships. Fixation: Neurotic disorders Stage V: Genital 11-13 years until young adulthood Genital The ego is fully developed and seeks independence and meaningful relationships. Fixation: Neurotic disorders Reference: Freud's Developmental Theory - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf

questions.question: A child accidentally trips over a toy car and scolds it, saying, "Bad car! You made me fall!". The child believes the toy can cause harm intentionally. Which stage of cognitive development is the child in?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Preoperational Explanation: The child is giving the car life-like qualities. This is animistic thinking seen in the preoperational stage of cognitive development. Piaget’s Stages of Cognitive Development: Cognitive Stage Key Achievements Sensorimotor (Option A) Birth to 2 years Infants "think" with their senses (eyes, ears, and touch). Object permanence develops. Improved memory and make-believe play. Mental representation (symbolization) by 18 months Preoperational (Option B) 2 to 7 years Egocentric thinking dominates. Animistic thinking: Objects are given life-like qualities. Use of symbols in play. Development of language. Concrete Operations (Option C) 7 to 11 years Logical thinking develops. Understanding of conservation (weight, volume, matter). Ability to classify objects hierarchically. Reversibility (can mentally reverse actions). Formal Operations (Option D) 11 years through the end of adolescence Hypothetical-deductive reasoning develops. Imaginary audience- everyone is looking at them Personal fable- inflated opinion of themselves Propositional or abstract thinking Reference: Kaplan & Saddock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th Edition, Page 2801-2804

questions.question: Which of the following findings in Pavlov’s experiment explains extinction?

options.B: Dogs stopped salivating on seeing food
options.C: Dogs started salivating at sounds associated with food
options.D: Dogs stopped salivating at sounds associated with food

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Dogs stopped salivating at sounds associated with food Explanation: Extinction is when the conditioned response (salivating at sounds associated with food arriving) weakens and disappears. Classical conditioning: Unconscious learning method in which an automatic, conditioned response is paired with specific stimuli. Pavlov’s Experiment with Dogs- At first, the dogs would only salivate when the food was placed in front of them. However, later they salivated slightly before their food arrived at the noises related to food arrival; for example, the sound of an approaching food cart. Here, Unconditioned stimulus- food Unconditioned response- salivation on seeing the food Conditioned stimulus- sound associated with food Conditioned response- salivation on sounds associated with food Extinction Stimulus Generalization Definition The conditioned response weakens and eventually disappears due to the conditioned stimulus being presented without the unconditioned stimulus. A conditioned response is elicited by stimuli that are similar to the conditioned stimulus. Example If Pavlov rang the bell (conditioned stimulus) without presenting food (unconditioned stimulus), the dogs would eventually stop salivating at the sound of the bell (conditioned response) If Pavlov’s dogs salivated in response to a sound similar to the bell, such as a cell phone ringing, this would illustrate stimulus generalization. Reference: Classical Conditioning

questions.question: Which of the following describes negative reinforcement?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Removing an unfavorable stimulus Explanation: Negative reinforcement is removing an unfavorable stimulus (e.g., restrictions or unpleasant tasks) to increase behavior. Operant Conditioning - deals with how environmental events control voluntary behavior Positive reinforcement Adding a favorable stimulus (e.g., money or praise) to increase behavior . (Option A ruled out) Negative reinforcement Removing an unfavorable stimulus (e.g., restrictions or unpleasant tasks) to increase behavior. (Option B) Positive punishment Adding an unfavorable stimulus (e.g., a physical blow or loud noise) to decrease behavior. (Option C ruled out) Negative punishment Removing a favorable stimulus (e.g., money or privileges) to decrease behavior. (Option D ruled out) Absence of reinforcement/punishment No consequence, leading to a likely decrease in behavior. Reference: Operant Conditioning - an overview

questions.question: Which of the following is the most widely used projective personality test?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Rorschach Inkblot Test Explanation: The most widely used projective personality test is the Rorschach Test Projective personality tests - psychological assessments that use ambiguous stimuli, such as images or words, to elicit responses that reflect the individual's thoughts, feelings, and experiences. Name of the test Description Rorschach Inkblot Test (Option A) 10 stimulus cards of inkblots are shown and the examiner records verbatim what the patient says. The most widely used projective device Thematic Apperception Test (TAT) (Option B) 20 stimulus cards depicting various scenes of ambiguity Patients create stories based on the pictures Sentence Completion Test Patients receive a series of incomplete sentences to complete with their first response. Holtzman Inkblot Technique (HIT) (Option C) Two parallel forms of inkblot cards with 45 cards per form Only one response is allowed per card Figure Drawing (Option D) Typically involves human forms, houses, or other figures Make-a-Picture Story (MAPS) Similar to TAT; stimuli can be manipulated by the patient

questions.question: A 45-year-old man has recently experienced several setbacks, including the loss of his job and difficulties in his marriage. He expresses a sense of failure and a fear that his life lacks purpose, and he feels disconnected from his community and his family. According to Erikson's stages of psychosocial development, which stage is he most likely struggling with?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Generativity vs. Stagnation Explanation: Erikson's stage of Generativity vs. Stagnation, typically encountered during middle adulthood (40–65 years), involves a focus on contributing to society and helping the next generation. Failure to achieve this leads to feelings of stagnation and a lack of purpose, as seen in the patient's symptoms. Erik Erikson's theory of psychosocial development identifies eight stages of development: Stage 1 Trust vs. Mistrust (Birth to 18 months) Infants learn to trust or mistrust the world based on the consistency of care from their caregivers. Stage 2 Autonomy vs. Shame and Doubt (18 months to 3 years) Children develop a sense of personal control and independence or feel shame and doubt about their abilities. Stage 3 Initiative vs. Guilt (3 years to 5 years) Children assert power and control over their environment, leading to a sense of initiative or feelings of guilt. (Option B) Stage 4 Industry vs. Inferiority (5 years to 13 years) Children develop self-confidence in abilities when competent or a sense of inferiority when not. (Option A) Stage 5 Identity vs. Role Confusion (13 years to 21 years) Adolescents explore their personal identity and values or become confused about their role in life. Stage 6 Intimacy vs. Isolation (21 years to 40 years) Young adults form deep, meaningful relationships, or experience loneliness and isolation. Stage 7 Generativity vs. Stagnation (40 years to 60 years) Adults seek to contribute to society and future generations, or feel stagnant and disconnected from broader purposes. Stage 8 Integrity vs. Despair (60 years to death) Older adults reflect on their life, either feeling a sense of fulfilment and integrity, or regret and despair. (Option D) Reference: Kaplan & Saddock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th Edition, Pages 3370-3378
